page.title: 10Landscape, Scoutmoor.
page.content: The dam of{Great Lodge}was removed by the North West Water Authority in 1984. Today the site looks like a dried-up lake bed. It was constructed about 1840 by John Haworth, a farmer, who together with the Ashworths and Ramsbottoms had developed the mills in the Cheesden Valley some years earlier. Great Lodge was built to overcome the problem of an irregular flow of water and provided a valuable service in regulating the work of the mills, by the use of sluice gates. With the decline of the textile mills in the 20th Centuary the need for this service has disappeared, and so the former Lodge remains as a dried-up reservoir at present.
